text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Colitis
Colitis is inflammation of the colon. Colitis may last a short time (be acute), or it may last a long time (become chronic).
What are the causes?
This condition may be caused by:
• Viruses.
• Bacteria.
• Reaction to medicine.
• Certain autoimmune diseases such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis.
• Radiation treatment.
• Decreased blood flow to the bowel (ischemia).
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Watery diarrhea.
• Passing bloody or tarry stool.
• Pain.
• Fever.
• Vomiting.
• Tiredness (fatigue).
• Weight loss.
• Bloating.
• Abdominal pain.
• Having fewer bowel movements than usual.
• A strong and sudden urge to have a bowel movement.
• Feeling like the bowel is not empty after a bowel movement.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition is diagnosed with a stool test or a blood test.
You may also have other tests, such as:
• X-rays.
• CT scan.
• Colonoscopy.
• Endoscopy.
• Biopsy.
How is this treated?
Treatment for this condition depends on the cause. The condition may be treated by:
• Resting the bowel. This involves not eating or drinking for a period of time.
• Fluids that are given through an IV.
• Medicine for pain and diarrhea.
• Antibiotic medicines.
• Cortisone medicines.
• Surgery.
Follow these instructions at home:
Eating and drinking
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about eating or drinking restrictions.
• Drink enough fluid to keep your urine pale yellow.
• Work with a dietitian to determine which foods cause your condition to flare up.
• Avoid foods that cause flare-ups.
• Eat a well-balanced diet.
General instructions
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the antibiotic even if you start to feel better.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• Your symptoms do not go away.
• You develop new symptoms.
Get help right away if you:
• Have a fever that does not go away with treatment.
• Develop chills.
• Have extreme weakness, fainting, or dehydration.
• Have repeated vomiting.
• Develop severe pain in your abdomen.
• Pass bloody or tarry stool.
Summary
• Colitis is inflammation of the colon. Colitis may last a short time (be acute), or it may last a long time (become chronic).
• Treatment for this condition depends on the cause and may include resting the bowel, taking medicines, or having surgery.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the antibiotic even if you start to feel better.
• Get help right away if you develop severe pain in your abdomen.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2019-09-20 Document Reviewed: 2019-09-20
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Duodenitis
Duodenitis is inflammation of the lining of the first part of the small intestine (duodenum). It is commonly caused by an infection from bacteria, which may also lead to open sores (ulcers) in the intestine.
Duodenitis may develop suddenly and last for a short time (acute), or it may develop gradually and last for months or years (chronic).
What are the causes?
The most common cause of duodenitis is an infection from a type of bacteria called Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori). Other causes of this condition include:
• Long-term use of NSAIDs.
• Excessive use of alcohol.
• An infection of the small intestine caused by the Giardia parasite (giardiasis).
• Crohn's disease.
• Certain diseases of the body's defense system (immune system).
• Certain treatments for cancer.
What increases the risk?
The following factors may make you more likely to develop this condition:
• Smoking cigarettes.
• Drinking alcohol.
• Having a family history of duodenitis.
• Taking NSAIDs.
• Eating a high-fat diet.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition may include:
• Gnawing or burning pain in the upper center of the abdomen (epigastric pain). This may get worse when the stomach is empty and may get better after eating.
• Abdominal cramps.
• Nausea and vomiting.
• Bloody vomit.
• Stools that are bloody, dark, or look like tar.
• Diarrhea.
• Weight loss.
• Fatigue.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition may be diagnosed based on your medical history and a physical exam. You may also have tests, such as:
• Blood tests.
• Stool tests.
• A test that checks the gases in your breath.
• An X-ray that is done after you swallow a liquid (barium) that makes your digestive tract easier to see.
• Endoscopy. This is an exam of the duodenum that is done by putting a thin tube with a tiny camera on the end (endoscope) down your throat. A sample of tissue from your duodenum (biopsy) may be removed with the endoscope and examined under a microscope for signs of inflammation and infection.
How is this treated?
Treatment depends on the cause of your condition. Treatment may include:
• Antibiotic medicine to treat H. pylori infection.
• Stopping your intake of NSAIDs.
• Medicine to reduce stomach acids.
• Medicines to treat other conditions, such as Crohn's disease or giardiasis.
• Surgery to treat severe inflammation that causes scarring or severe bleeding.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the antibiotic even if you start to feel better.
Eating and drinking
• Eat small, frequent meals.
• Do not drink alcohol.
• Drink enough water to keep your urine pale yellow.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about eating or drinking restrictions. You may be asked to avoid:
◦ Caffeinated drinks.
◦ Chocolate.
◦ Peppermint or mint-flavored food or drinks.
◦ Garlic or onions.
◦ Spicy foods.
◦ Citrus fruits.
◦ Tomato-based foods.
◦ Fatty or fried foods.
General instructions
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes and e-cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have a fever.
• Your symptoms come back, get worse, or do not get better with treatment.
Get help right away if:
• You vomit blood.
• You have severe abdominal pain.
• Your abdomen swells and is painful.
• You have a lot of blood in your stool.
• You feel dizzy or light-headed.
Summary
• Duodenitis is inflammation of the lining of the first part of the small intestine. This part of the small intestine is called the duodenum.
• Duodenitis may develop suddenly and last for a short time (acute), or it may develop gradually and last longer (chronic).
• The most common cause of duodenitis is an infection from a type of bacteria.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2019-07-10 Document Reviewed: 2019-07-10
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Gastritis, Adult
Gastritis is inflammation of the stomach. There are two kinds of gastritis:
• Acute gastritis. This kind develops suddenly.
• Chronic gastritis. This kind is much more common and lasts for a long time.
Gastritis happens when the lining of the stomach becomes weak or gets damaged. Without treatment, gastritis can lead to stomach bleeding and ulcers.
What are the causes?
This condition may be caused by:
• An infection.
• Drinking too much alcohol.
• Certain medicines. These include steroids, antibiotics, and some over-the-counter medicines, such as aspirin or ibuprofen.
• Having too much acid in the stomach.
• A disease of the intestines or stomach.
• Stress.
• An allergic reaction.
• Crohn's disease.
• Some cancer treatments (radiation).
Sometimes the cause of this condition is not known.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Pain or a burning sensation in the upper abdomen.
• Nausea.
• Vomiting.
• An uncomfortable feeling of fullness after eating.
• Weight loss.
• Bad breath.
• Blood in your vomit or stools.
In some cases, there are no symptoms.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition may be diagnosed with:
• Your medical history and a description of your symptoms.
• A physical exam.
• Tests. These can include:
◦ Blood tests.
◦ Stool tests.
◦ A test in which a thin, flexible instrument with a light and a camera is passed down the esophagus and into the stomach (upper endoscopy).
◦ A test in which a sample of tissue is taken for testing (biopsy).
How is this treated?
This condition may be treated with medicines. The medicines that are used vary depending on the cause of the gastritis:
• If the condition is caused by a bacterial infection, you may be given antibiotic medicines.
• If the condition is caused by too much acid in the stomach, you may be given medicines called H2 blockers, proton pump inhibitors, or antacids.
Treatment may also involve stopping the use of certain medicines, such as aspirin, ibuprofen, or other NSAIDs.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your health care provider. Do not stop taking the antibiotic even if you start to feel better.
Eating and drinking
• Eat small, frequent meals instead of large meals.
• Avoid foods and drinks that make your symptoms worse.
• Drink enough fluid to keep your urine pale yellow.
Alcohol use
• Do not drink alcohol if:
◦ Your health care provider tells you not to drink.
◦ You are pregnant, may be pregnant, or are planning to become pregnant.
• If you drink alcohol:
◦ Limit your use to:
▪ 0–1 drink a day for women.
▪ 0–2 drinks a day for men.
◦ Be aware of how much alcohol is in your drink. In the U.S., one drink equals one 12 oz bottle of beer (355 mL), one 5 oz glass of wine (148 mL), or one 1½ oz glass of hard liquor (44 mL).
General instructions
• Talk with your health care provider about ways to manage stress, such as getting regular exercise or practicing deep breathing, meditation, or yoga.
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes and e-cigarettes. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• Your symptoms get worse.
• Your symptoms return after treatment.
Get help right away if:
• You vomit blood or material that looks like coffee grounds.
• You have black or dark red stools.
• You are unable to keep fluids down.
• Your abdominal pain gets worse.
• You have a fever.
• You do not feel better after one week.
Summary
• Gastritis is inflammation of the lining of the stomach that can occur suddenly (acute) or develop slowly over time (chronic).
• This condition is diagnosed with a medical history, a physical exam, or tests.
• This condition may be treated with medicines to treat infection or medicines to reduce the amount of acid in your stomach.
• Follow your health care provider's instructions about taking medicines, making changes to your diet, and knowing when to call for help.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2019-08-07 Document Reviewed: 2019-08-07
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Colonoscopy, Adult, Care After
This sheet gives you information about how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to have:
• A small amount of blood in your stool for 24 hours after the procedure.
• Some gas.
• Mild cramping or bloating of your abdomen.
Follow these instructions at home:
Eating and drinking
• Drink enough fluid to keep your urine pale yellow.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about eating or drinking restrictions.
• Resume your normal diet as instructed by your health care provider. Avoid heavy or fried foods that are hard to digest.
Activity
• Rest as told by your health care provider.
• Avoid sitting for a long time without moving. Get up to take short walks every 1–2 hours. This is important to improve blood flow and breathing. Ask for help if you feel weak or unsteady.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
Managing cramping and bloating
• Try walking around when you have cramps or feel bloated.
• Apply heat to your abdomen as told by your health care provider. Use the heat source that your health care provider recommends, such as a moist heat pack or a heating pad.
◦ Place a towel between your skin and the heat source.
◦ Leave the heat on for 20–30 minutes.
◦ Remove the heat if your skin turns bright red. This is especially important if you are unable to feel pain, heat, or cold. You may have a greater risk of getting burned.
General instructions
• For the first 24 hours after the procedure:
◦ Do not drive or use machinery.
◦ Do not sign important documents.
◦ Do not drink alcohol.
◦ Do your regular daily activities at a slower pace than normal.
◦ Eat soft foods that are easy to digest.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have blood in your stool 2–3 days after the procedure.
Get help right away if you have:
• More than a small spotting of blood in your stool.
• Large blood clots in your stool.
• Swelling of your abdomen.
• Nausea or vomiting.
• A fever.
• Increasing pain in your abdomen that is not relieved with medicine.
Summary
• After the procedure, it is common to have a small amount of blood in your stool. You may also have mild cramping and bloating of your abdomen.
• For the first 24 hours after the procedure, do not drive or use machinery, sign important documents, or drink alcohol.
• Get help right away if you have a lot of blood in your stool, nausea or vomiting, a fever, or increased pain in your abdomen.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-10-13 Document Reviewed: 2020-10-13
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Upper Endoscopy, Adult, Care After
This sheet gives you information about how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to have:
• A sore throat.
• Mild stomach pain or discomfort.
• Bloating.
• Nausea.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about what to eat or drink after your procedure.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Do not drive for 24 hours if you were given a sedative during your procedure.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if you have:
• A sore throat that lasts longer than one day.
• Trouble swallowing.
Get help right away if:
• You vomit blood or your vomit looks like coffee grounds.
• You have:
◦ A fever.
◦ Bloody, black, or tarry stools.
◦ A severe sore throat or you cannot swallow.
◦ Difficulty breathing.
◦ Severe pain in your chest or abdomen.
Summary
• After the procedure, it is common to have a sore throat, mild stomach discomfort, bloating, and nausea.
• Do not drive for 24 hours if you were given a sedative during the procedure.
• Follow instructions from your health care provider about what to eat or drink after your procedure.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2019-09-11 Document Reviewed: 2019-08-20
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.
